diagnosis.score_summary: The brand is fundamentally split between a 'Cool' lifestyle identity on the Storefront and a 'Clinical' emergency kit on the PDP. You are trying to be a cosmetic beauty brand (WWW) while selling a pharmaceutical trauma tool (PDP).

truth_1.headline: The Pop Art Placebo
truth_1.gap_description: WWW uses orange as 'Dopamine' (Pop/Vibes). PDP uses orange as 'Hazard' (Warning/Safety). You are using the same hex code to signal two opposite psychological triggers.
truth_1.why_matters: Visual physics matter. The Storefront suggests a fun, daily beauty oil. The PDP delivers a serious medical instruction leaflet. The customer feels like they bought a toy but received a prescription.
truth_1.the_hard_choice: You are treating the color orange like a mood ring when it needs to be a signal. The data demands a choice: either clean up the Storefront to match the sterile authority of the PDP (Option A), or warm up the PDP to match the 'Gen-Z' energy of the Storefront (Option B). You cannot be a party and a hospital at the same time.

truth_2.headline: Status vs. Trauma
truth_2.gap_description: WWW positions the user as 'Savvy' (buying a cool product). PDP addresses a user in 'Panic' (fixing a scar). One is about social signaling; the other is about medical relief.
truth_2.why_matters: This is an empathy failure. You are greeting a traumatized customer (scar/surgery) with a 'cool girl' attitude on the Storefront. It minimizes their pain and erodes trust.
truth_2.the_hard_choice: Your Storefront is playing to an audience that wants to look smart, while your product page is saving people who are scared of their own reflection. You must decide: either pivot the entire brand to 'Beauty Enhancement' and lose the medical credibility (Option A), or honor the 'Trauma' reality across all touchpoints and drop the fashion posturing (Option B). Real medicine doesn't try to be cool.

truth_3.headline: The Transaction Trap
truth_3.gap_description: WWW is a 'Hard Sell' engine (transaction focused). PDP is a 'Science Class' (education focused). Usually, this is reversed. Your top-funnel (WWW) is aggressive, while your bottom-funnel (PDP) is passive.
truth_3.evidence: WWW: 'Hard Product Sell' (Intent 5/5) vs. PDP: 'Science Education' (Intent 1/5)
truth_3.why_matters: You are pushing for the sale before you have explained the science. The Storefront assumes the user is already sold, while the PDP assumes they know nothing. The funnel is inverted.
truth_3.the_hard_choice: You are yelling 'Buy Now' at people who are still asking 'How does it work?' You face a binary choice: either dumb down the PDP to a transactional vending machine (Option A), or elevate the Storefront to an educational hub that explains the 'PurCellin' science before asking for the credit card (Option B). Closing the deal requires opening the mind first.

truth_4.headline: The Cold Doctor
truth_4.gap_description: WWW creates warmth (Affectionate 4/5). PDP creates distance (Distant 2/5). The brand lures people in with a hug and then puts on a lab coat and gloves.
truth_4.why_matters: Inconsistency in emotional temperature feels like a betrayal. The 'Caregiver' archetype works on both, but the execution differs. The Storefront feels human; the PDP feels corporate.
truth_4.the_hard_choice: Your personality is drifting from 'Your Best Friend' to 'Your Surgeon.' You must choose the relationship model: either strip the emotion from the Storefront to align with the clinical reality (Option A), or inject empathy into the PDP technical specs to maintain the human connection (Option B). A doctor who smiles and then goes cold is terrifying.

truth_5.headline: The Secret Ingredient
truth_5.gap_description: WWW vaguely mentions 'Natural plant oils.' PDP aggressively claims 'PurCellin Oil' (a proprietary lab copy). The PDP is winning because it sells the unique mechanism, not just the category.
truth_5.evidence: USP Ownership: PDP (The System 5/5) > WWW (The Hero 2/5)
truth_5.why_matters: The PDP proves that customers want the 'Science,' not just the 'Nature.' The Storefront is hiding your biggest weapon (PurCellin) behind generic 'Plant Oil' marketing.
truth_5.the_hard_choice: The Storefront is ashamed of your synthetic engineering, but the PDP proves it is your greatest asset. You are at a crossroads: either embrace the 'Lab Breakthrough' globally and sell PurCellin as the hero (Option A), or continue the 'Natural' charade and risk being commoditized by generic oils (Option B). Nature is free; Science is valuable.

marker_1.so_what: Strategic lock. Both channels agree that the brand exists to fix damage, not just moisturize. This singular focus on pathology is the brand's anchor.

marker_2.so_what: Perfect alignment on scope and access. You are selling a specific fix to the masses. There is no confusion about who this is for or what it does.

marker_3.so_what: A dangerous split. WWW prioritizes 'Safety' (do no harm), while PDP prioritizes 'Efficacy' (get results). You are promising a gentle touch on one side and a heavy hammer on the other.

marker_4.so_what: The territory matches, but the execution drifts. The Storefront tries to elevate the price perception to 'Masstige', while the PDP grounds it as a $10 utility staple.

marker_5.so_what: The authority is consistent, but the warmth is not. The Storefront wants to be a friend; the PDP wants to be a clinician. This creates an emotional 'uncanny valley'.

marker_6.so_what: The soul of the brand is intact. The Caregiver/Sage mix (Healing + Knowledge) is dominant across both channels, providing a stable psychological foundation.

marker_7.so_what: The voice is shifting from 'Helpful' on the Storefront to 'Grave' on the PDP. The Storefront speaks like a consultant; the PDP speaks like a warning label.

marker_8.so_what: Total visual disconnect. The Storefront is an art project; the PDP is a medical chart. You are selling two different products: a lifestyle accessory vs. a medical supply.

marker_9.so_what: The hook is solid. Both channels ignore fluff and go straight to the problem (scars/stretch marks). This discipline is a major conversion driver.

marker_10.so_what: A conflict of origin. WWW implies a 'Studio/Nature' setting (Green Lab), while PDP insists on a 'Sterile/Synthetic' setting. You can't be both a botanical garden and a clean room.

marker_11.so_what: The authority source is locked. 'Dermatologist Recommended' is the trump card across both channels. This consistency creates a strong trust halo.

marker_12.so_what: The PDP is much more aggressive in claiming ownership of the 'System' (PurCellin) and the 'Condition' (Trauma). The Storefront is softer, relying on brand fame rather than technical superiority.

marker_13.so_what: The intent is inverted. The 'Store' is treating the user like a wallet, while the 'Product Page' is treating them like a student. The educational heavy lifting should happen earlier in the journey.

marker_14.so_what: Perfect alignment on the 'What'. Both channels promise to reverse visible damage. This clarity on the 'Fixer' role is why the product sells.

marker_15.so_what: A massive empathy gap. WWW tells the user they are making a smart lifestyle choice. PDP treats them like a patient in recovery. The emotional promise is completely totally disjointed.

marker_16.so_what: Both channels agree: this is not a 'cool' brand, it's a 'standard' brand. It's the WD-40 of skin. Embracing this pragmatism works.

marker_17.so_what: The social contract is clear: buy this to look normal again. The focus on 'Normalization' rather than 'Excellence' is consistent and powerful.
